summary: Gabriel Mannarino was a key figure in anti-racketeering activities in Pittsburgh and surrounding areas, heavily involved in gambling and loan sharking operations. FBI documents from 1961 detail his activities, including expanding operations into Pittsburgh by taking over Lloyds, Limited as a front. He was planning to purchase or lease the Anchorage Road House to move his gambling operation. His gambling activities extended to a farm in Westmoreland County, PA. He was associated with Willie Sams, who was involved in his gambling operations and investigated for potentially being a tipster or informant. The FBI considered Gabriel Mannarino to be armed and dangerous. His activities were under increased law enforcement pressure, leading to the suppression of gambling in New Kensington, PA.
significance: The documents suggest Gabriel Mannarino was a significant figure in organized crime in the Pittsburgh area during the early 1960s. While the documents don't directly link him to the JFK assassination, his connections to other individuals mentioned in the documents (such as Joe Campisi) who have been subjects of speculation and investigation in the JFK context, could be of interest. The documents highlight the FBI's focus on his gambling and racketeering activities, providing a glimpse into the criminal underworld of the time.
